resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: <span style="color: #374151; font-family: Söhne, ui-sans-serif, system-ui, -apple-system, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Noto Sans', sans-serif, 'Helvetica Neue', Arial, 'Apple Color Emoji', 'Segoe UI Emoji', 'Segoe UI Symbol', 'Noto Color Emoji'; font-size: 16px; white-space-collapse: preserve;">This image of a corpse is quite ambivalent. The deceased has one foot in the grave, illustrating the ambiguous situation of the excommunicated who is absolved. Through the presence of a part of the corpse in a tomb, the image emphasizes the distancing and loss of the connection with God. However, being absolved, the deceased is shown emerging from the tomb with signs of life, alluding to a positive divine action. Nevertheless, it is not a classic return to life; it is extraordinary. He returns to life in a very temporary way, unlike the classic resurrections performed by God.
resource.chars: This image of a corpse is quite ambivalent. The deceased has one foot in the grave, illustrating the ambiguous situation of the excommunicated who is absolved. Through the presence of a part of the corpse in a tomb, the image emphasizes the distancing and loss of the connection with God. However, being absolved, the deceased is shown emerging from the tomb with signs of life, alluding to a positive divine action. Nevertheless, it is not a classic return to life; it is extraordinary. He returns to life in a very temporary way, unlike the classic resurrections performed by God.

resource.http://dev.llgc.org.uk/sas/full_text: The marginalized corpse, yet showing signs of life. This representation serves to underline the mediocrity of the human condition while indicating the possibility of elevation
